newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Mandela told not to send S.African troops to Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Mandela told not to send S.African troops to Zaire.

text.p: A South African task force urged President Nelson Mandela on Friday to help find a political solution instead of sending troops to strife-torn Central Africa, state television reported.

Foreign Affairs director-general Rusty Evans said the team, which included senior military officers sent by Mandela to assess how Pretoria could help in Zaire, had advised against military intervention.

"We feel that there is a need for a political initiative in the Great Lakes area...And we have reported to President Mandela that South Africa should be willing...to contribute to that political diplomatic initiative," Evans told television news.

He said South Africa should immediately explore the possibility of giving technical assistance, such as a communications network. The delegation also agreed that a trust fund be set up to meet the cost of intervention.
Evans emphasised that the country's participation in the peace process would be guided by the decisions of other African countries.

South African Vice President Thabo Mbeki said earlier on Friday in Belgium his country was not prepared to send troops "to fight a war". He added that his country would not commit a force until a mandate was agreed.
"We would prefer a relatively limited number of people to be involved," Mbeki said. "Ideally they should be involved in security and distribution."
The United Nations is trying to negotiate with Rwanda and Zaire to deploy an international force to help distribute aid to hundreds of thousands of refugees.
Zaire's army is battling Rwandan-backed Tutsi rebels who are pursuing former Hutu soldiers of the Rwanda armed forces mixed with refugees from the 1994 Rwandan civil war.
